status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is over 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. Depending on the scope of work, part of or all of the street, may be posted at one time. To ensure as much parking as possible during construction we have instructed the contractor to only post the sections of the street that they will be working within the next week. This is why you see the contractors changing the dates on the signs.  If the work becomes more complicated than thought, they extended the no parking date. Or they move the signs down the street as the work progresses. This will allow more parking for the residents during construction. The CIU inspector will monitor the postings. Again the City apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Whenever a utility company or private contractor plans on excavating into the roadway or sidewalks, they must call Dig Safe. It is a State law. All of the other utilities near the pipe or conduit that plans to be excavated must be marked out in the interest of public safety. Paint has to be used, and it must be clearly visible. The City understands the frustration of dig safe markings. We are currently asking them to look into using paint that does not take as long to wear off. Bottom line, the paint marks are required, and eventually they will wear off. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. COMPLETED GRASS WERE CUT AND TRIMMED AT WORCESTER SQUARE 5/8/2017.
description:
Grass Mowing:

Is it too much to ask that the grass be cut a little longer than last year? When the sprinkler system was replaced several years ago, it no longer functions correctly when watering the grass. It does a fine job with the rosebushes but not the grass.

Last year, during the drought, the grass was dead since it was cut too close.

We've requested the sprinkler system be fixed to no avail.  In light of the diminished capacity of the system, we, the neighbors of Worcester Square, ask that the grass remain slightly longer so it doesn't dry out.

Feel free to contact me directly to discuss this matter.  Thank you.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent. . National Grid is replacing an almost 100 year old gas main on your street. The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. . The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. . However in the long run the construction is well worth it. . Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. We will make sure that the contractor does not start work before 7:00am.

status_notes: Case Noted. Contractors and residents in the City of Boston are allowed to post No Stopping signs if they have obtained a Street Occupancy Permit. Street Occupancy Permits are used to reserve parking spaces for things like moving trucks, dumpster and trucks making deliveries. There is a company in Boston that can be hired to obtain a permit on behalf of someone else and then that company will post the signs. The city actually requires that whoever obtains the permit, installs the signs. Signs do not need to be installed by the city or an agent for the city. The sign should contain a permit number which can be search for on the city's web site if there is a question about the validity of the permit.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. National Grid is replacing a gas main that is almost 100 years old. In addition to replacing a 100 year old main National Grid is replacing every gas service to each resident/business. The City highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs.   Especially if we plan on paving the street in the future. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However replacing mains over 100 years old ensures solid dependable gas service for another 100 years. They have signs indicating the work ahead and they have Police Officers on detail.  Sometimes the details are not filled. The inspector will monitor the worksite to ensure full compliance with the City's rules. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
